channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Majority of Minneapolis City Council Pledges to Dismantle Police Department
item.description: Some cities are starting to to heed calls to “defund the police,” as lawmakers push proposals for greater police accountability. National Guard troops are being sent home from Washington, D.C.
item.media:credit: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Powderhorn Park in Minneapolis on Sunday called for the defunding of the city’s Police Department.

item.title: George Floyd Protests Add New Front Line for Coronavirus Doctors
item.description: Many physicians wish to show solidarity at the demonstrations, but some fear a second wave of infection will follow.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Yuki Iwamura/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mount Sinai nurses and doctors cheered on protesters at Union Square in Manhattan on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Jumps the Border, Overwhelming Hospitals in California
item.description: Hospitals are airlifting patients to facilities hundreds of miles away to handle an influx of Americans and U.S. green card holders sickened in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler/Reuters
item.media:description: A health care worker in protective gear treated a patient with the coronavirus at the El Centro Regional Medical Center in El Centro, Calif., last month.

item.title: Biden and D.N.C. Raised Nearly $81 Million in May, a New High
item.description: The former vice president had struggled with fund-raising throughout much of the primary campaign, but the pace of giving has sharply increased.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s fund-raising haul in May was more than 30 percent higher than what he and the Democrats raised in April.

item.title: FDA Revokes Emergency Coronavirus Use of Malaria Drugs
item.description: The agency said that a review of some studies showed that the drugs’ potential benefits in treating Covid-19 did not outweigh the risks.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.category: Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority
item.media:credit: George Frey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Food and Drug Administration said that hydroxychloroquine was “unlikely to be effective” in treating the coronavirus.

item.title: Museums Embrace Art Therapy Techniques for Unsettled Times
item.description: Several institutions are preparing to reopen with an awareness of a new mission as people struggle with loss and unrest.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small

item.title: Portraits of Families in Protest
item.description: Parents actively show their children how to speak out and take a stand against inequality.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron and Cheriss May

item.title: Civil Rights Law Protects L.G.B.T. Workers, Supreme Court Rules
item.description: The court said the language of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which prohibits sex discrimination, applies to discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: RG & GR Harris Funeral Homes Inc
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tiffany Munroe during a rally to call attention to violence against transgender people of color in Brooklyn on Sunday.

item.title: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Case on California Sanctuary Law
item.description: The case concerned a state law that limits cooperation with agents seeking to detain immigrants released from state custody.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court gave no reasons why it declined to hear the case, as is its custom.

item.title: 25 Million Applications: The Scramble for N.Y.C. Affordable Housing
item.description: Entrants to the city’s housing lottery have waited years, through a tiresome and complex process. Now the system is getting an overhaul.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Atlanta Police Shooting Live Updates: Full Analysis
item.description: The district attorney has said he will decide by midweek on whether to file criminal charges in the fatal police shooting of Rayshard Brooks.
item.media:credit: Joshua Rashaad McFadden for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest at the Wendy’s in Atlanta on Sunday, where Rayshard Brooks was shot and killed by police on Friday.

item.title: How to Donate Blood
item.description: What you need to know about donating in a time of crisis.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Wartik
item.media:credit: Jon Nazca/Reuters

item.title: How One California High School Celebrated Graduation During a Pandemic
item.description: The students and parents pushed and prodded over 10 weeks for an exception to Gov. Gavin Newsom’s shelter-in-place order.
item.dc:creator: Anne Daugherty
item.media:credit: Anne Daugherty
item.media:description: After arriving on Paradise High School’s Om Wraith field for the school’s first ever drive-in graduation ceremony, Brian Enright, a senior, takes in the scene.

item.title: Trump’s Niece to Publish Book With ‘Harrowing’ Revelations, Report Says
item.description: The Daily Beast reported that Mary Trump will also say that she was a source of The New York Times’s coverage of the president’s tax returns. The Times declined to comment on the claim.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump walking off Air Force One at Joint Base Andrews, Md., on Sunday.

item.title: A Killing in Atlanta Stirs Fresh Anger
item.description: New arguments on defunding vs. restructuring the police: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: U.S. Fighter Jet Crashes in Britain, With One Pilot Aboard
item.description: The British authorities were searching for the pilot, whose status American officials said was “unknown at this time.”
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: How Trump Is Fueling Progressivism
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump with African-American supporters at the White House last week.

item.title: ‘Troubling Tableau’ in 11th Circuit’s Prisoner Cases, Sotomayor Says
item.description: The appeals court, which covers three Southern states, uses procedures “out of step with other courts,” Justice Sonia Sotomayor wrote, echoing critiques from judges and scholars.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Eduardo Munoz/Reuters
item.media:description: Justice Sonia Sotomayor voiced her criticism after the Supreme Court turned down a petition asking it to consider the 11th Circuit’s practices.

item.title: The Rising Trump Lawyer Battling to Reshape the Electorate
item.description: He’s argued against affirmative action at Harvard and abortion in Georgia. Now he has a leading role as Republicans push a new wave of voting measures across the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim and Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: William Consovoy mixes Jersey guy affability with an affinity for some of the most divisive culture-wars legal disputes.

item.title: Live Market Tracker: Stocks Wobble as New Outbreaks Emerge
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Ann Saphir/Reuters
item.media:description: “We can’t wait 10 years for an economic recovery to reach everyone,” said Mary Daly, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank San Francisco.

item.title: Police Chiefs Are Finding Job Security Is Hard to Come By
item.description: Chiefs who promise reform must find a way to satisfy local officials, the police and their union, and a public that is increasingly critical of police tactics and behavior.
item.dc:creator: Shaila Dewan
item.media:credit: David Goldman/Associated Press
item.media:description: Police Chief Erika Shields of Atlanta in 2018. Ms. Shields resigned shortly after the fatal shooting of Rayshard Brooks by an Atlanta police officer on Friday.

item.title: A War Against Climate Science, Waged by Washington’s Rank and File
item.description: Efforts to block research on climate change don’t just come from the Trump political appointees on top. Lower managers in government are taking their cues, and running with them.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The headquarters of the Department of Interior in Washington.

item.title: The Pandemic Claims New Victims: Prestigious Medical Journals
item.description: Two major study retractions in one month have left researchers wondering if the peer review process is broken.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: The rush to publish during the pandemic may be threatening the credibility of respected medical journals.

item.title: Police Killings Prompt Reassessment of Laws Allowing Deadly Force
item.description: The continuing deaths of black people by the police are undermining support for the wide latitude officers are given in cases in which an encounter ends in a death.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Joshua Rashaad McFadden for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest at the Wendy’s in Atlanta on Sunday, where Rayshard Brooks was shot and killed by police on Friday.

item.title: Author Frances Cha on Achieving the Feminine Ideal
item.description: The author of “If I Had Your Face,” discusses her debut novel — a story of four women pursuing dreams and ambitions in fiercely competitive Seoul.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seligson
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Frances Cha, the author of “If I Had Your Face,” in Marlton, N.J.

item.title: Families Challenge Suicide in Deaths of Black Men Found Hanging From Trees
item.description: The bodies of Robert Fuller and Malcolm Harsch were found in California, 10 days and 50 miles apart. Their families are demanding deeper investigations.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia

item.title: Robert Gates Calls to Replace Base Names From ‘Dark Side of Our History’
item.description: The former defense secretary became the most senior previous military leader in recent days to endorse renaming 10 Army installations that bear the names of Confederate generals.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Joshua Roberts/Reuters
item.media:description: Former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates also said he did not support sending active-duty troops into American cities to put down demonstrations.

item.title: Tasers: Are These Police Tools Effective and Are They Dangerous?
item.description: The fatal police shooting of Rayshard Brooks in Atlanta has put a spotlight on a number of officer tactics, including the use of stun guns.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Mele and Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tasers can temporarily immobilize a person — think of someone who is combative or resisting arrest, for instance — by jolting them with 50,000 volts of electricity.

item.title: The Woman Who Took Down a Confederate Flag on What Came Next
item.description: Bree Newsome Bass was arrested after climbing a flagpole at the South Carolina State Capitol. Now, she sees more people moved to act for similar reasons.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa
item.media:credit: John Branch IV for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bree Newsome Bass has been an organizer in North Carolina focusing on housing rights for the last three years.

item.title: Events Like Trump Rally Are ‘Perfect Storm’ for Viral Spread, Experts Say
item.description: Social gatherings and campaign rallies like those planned by President Trump could spread infections this summer. People should wear masks and continue social distancing, public health researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: People dined on Saturday at tables set up outside Babette's on Newtown Lane in East Hampton, N.Y.
